name: Ari Novick
description: (this point is for testing/demonstration purposes) The Fish Hatch

name: Ari
description: There's a false path to the east here. Every time I've ever been at this point, the crew stops to debate which way to go. Scouting a minute down the false path reveals it's not a real path, so it's no big deal. But, the false path is usually muddy, so just keep that mind if it's really cold or a crewling has super-unwaterproofed boots.

name: Ari
description: If facilitating solos at Flat Laurel, I think this is without a doubt the best place to set up base camp. You'll know it when you see it. It's huge. Like you can fit a whole Bearmuda triangle in the site. And it's flat. And has a river. And bear hang trees. And good solo sites nearby. There's another good site 2 minutes southeast on the trail, but this one is better.

name: Ari
description: In August 2012 and August 2013, there were issues with bees at a point along this trail. I can't say exactly where, but I would guess it was about half way between D Boone and Deep Gap. It was about 6 minutes past (coming from D Boone) a high impact site, and it was right by some steps made from logs.

name: Unknown
description:
(this point is for testing/demonstration purposes)

Yeaaaahhhhh Boiiiiiii....HAWGS GONE WILD!!!!!!

name: Unknown
description: (this point is for testing/demonstration purposes)Mmmmm. Darn tootin good ice cream.

name: Ari
description: If you anticipate your crew being here, make sure to bring a sharpie on the trail.

name: Ky~e
description:
There is a natural rockbed waterslide that is just across the street from the Cove gate and no one from the institutional memories of 2013 knew it existed (discovered August 2012, Aisha knows where it is!). From the road, go a few steps down the trail leading to fish hatch and there should be a small side trail leading down to a campsite. Keep following the path through the right side of the campsite going away from the road and you should end up at a river spot with a narrow waterfall rockslide leading into a swimming hole. 

Mothers and their children were sliding down safely so our crew joined in on the fun, but it could be black zone to some.

name: Ross
description: Pipe for water located on the jeep track at the Black Balsam parking lot

name: Vern
description: There isn't much to be desired for camping spots around this area. So if crewlings are like yay gap we'll stop there for the night, try to non-directly push them away from that thought. Horse cove gap is about the same as welll

name: Scott
description: Several high impact campsites. Small stream for water. Near the top of an awesome waterfall/cliff.

name: Emily Stout
description: Due to some unforeseen circumstances, my March 2014 crew was dropped off here. If for some reason you ever hike this trail, pack Chacos or Crocs - we did 8 legit, take-out-your-soles-and-unbuckle-your-pack river crossings in the span of a mile. In other news, though, there's a gorgeous campsite along this ridge. :)

name: Eleanor
description: Pipe for water part way up the trail to Cold Mountain

name: Eleanor
description: Pipe for water slightly south of Shining Rock on Art Loeb. Not a lot of other water sources around.

name: Eleanor
description: Camping at Ivestor Gap is quite exposed and windy. Maybe not the best place on March if it is expected to be cold.

name: Eleanor
description: Camping at Ivestor Gap is quite exposed and windy. Not ideal for cold nights on March.

name: Eleanor
description: Camping at Ivestor Gap is quite windy and exposed. Not ideal for cold nights on March.

name: Eleanor
description: If starting at D-Boone make sure to get an early drop off and motivate your crew to get moving! First place to camp is Deep Gap and it's a long uphill battle to there.

name: Ky~e
description: Incredible view and great photo spot that is often missed. Coming up from the wall-of-death, turn left towards Devil's Courthouse, take ~16 steps, and carefully walk down a little side trail on the left towards the edge.

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: The Rock Quarry!

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: Daytime rock quarry parking

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: Midnight rock quarry parking

name: Krkr
description:
There's a waterfall here which is one of my favorite places in Pisgah.

Note: it may actually be at the next valley, "BM AKW 227" on the USGS map. I can't actually remember - but if you're taking this trail you're gonna hit both, because there's no other way to go.

It's - sublime. Because it's one of those places that's always empty. This trail is rarely taken and somehow seems more 'primordial' than the others. You'll be laying in a little pool of water on the top of the falls and staring up into the towering greenth and you'll feel like you did on your first trip - like there's no civilization for twenty miles in every direction.

Also, we found a crayfish in the top of the falls here, which really makes me wonder. How could it have survived there? These streams filter down from the edge of the BRP. It and its brethren must have been in these hills for thousands or millions of years.

Note that this trail is especially tedious to reach from the road, so don't try anything silly.

name: Krkr
description:
There's an excellent swimming hole around here which was dubbed 'Andy's Bridge of Death' years before I visited it - legend has it that someone named Andy broke their leg there by jumping off of the bridge.

Jumping off of the rocks is safe and lovely (try it in March!). But jumping off the bridge - no. Don't do that.

I was never clear on whether it was here or a bit up the trail, or if the 'Yellowstone Falls' marker is actually referring to it.

name: Ari
description: Great VAM. It's right on the trail, but isn't obvious. You need to climb over and onto the other side of the rock. You know you're at the spot I'm talking about because it's two steps before/after the open field on this trail.

name: Bobby and Noelle
description: Dank-ass (aka good) campsite a couple switchbacks up from Glocester down to your left as you head up to Pilot. Hidden behind a big rock, has an epic view.

name: Bobby
description: Water here ranges from a small brook to nothing, depending on rain fall. If any, it will cross under the Art Loeb near the A-frame turn off closest to Pilot.

name: Noelle
description: Graveyard site for solos...creepy

name: Bobby and Noelle
description: This area is suuuper confusing (which lead to much chaos for the 2011 mongols)

name: Bobby
description: Sub-par campsite here, but It is the only one between Wagon Ridge and Graveyard fields.

name: Bobby and Noelle
description: Exxxxtremely steep trail. The real wall of death...

name: Bobby
description: There is a campsite hidden above/behind a big rock next to the parking lot. It is really only big enough for 4 man tents, so def don't try to tarp there. Also...it is technically illegal since it is in the area bordering the BRP, so don't let rangers see you...

name: Bobby and Noelle
description: Turn off for the Fun Run

name: Noelle
description: Great base camp for solos

name: Noelle
description: Epic hidden waterfall! Up the road a bit from where 105 hits the dirt road. Awesome to stop at if hiking into Cove.

name: Unknown
description: If you've never seen it, it's not super obvious that there's a body of water and rocks to jump off here. You have cross the stream, and then it's obvious.

name: Lizzie
description: Camped in a field at D-Boone in March 2014, thought we'd get in trouble with the ranger but instead he told us we could use the bathrooms in the heated dining hall. He did request that we check in with him in the future if we're planning to camp there for the night. Right now he lives in the camp master round house past the dining hall but is moving into a big house across the river next year, so go knock on his door for future march trips!

name: Tyler
description: Good campsite on the trail going around Sassafras Knob (the trail is only labelled on the USGS). The trail going over the top of Sassafras Knob is only labelled on the Nat Geo.

name: Isa Ferrall
description: 9 river crossings on a 1 mile stretch. Can be avoided with dirt road hiking

name: Ali
description: Lots of river crossings on Trail 133. Consider taking southern trail (322) if cold weather in March.

name: Bobby
description: The Ziegler Farm.

name: Bobby
description: Djibouti

name: Bobby
description: Djibouti crew campsite

name: Bobby
description: Bi Lo

name: Bobby
description: Transylvania Hospital Emergency Room

name: Bobby
description: Fox Mountain Guides (Where CD's get trained)

name: Bobby
description: Ingles (aka Black Mountain)

name: Bobby
description: Moose Cafe mmmmmmm

name: Bobby
description: High impact campsite

name: Bobby
description: Wall of Death...Hoka Hey

name: Bobby
description: Geological Survey Benchmark

name: Bobby
description: Geological Survey Benchmark

name: Bobby
description: Food hang torn down by "Berney" the black bear. August 2013. Pack found next day coated in a metric ton of bear slobber, torn to shreds. Berney went for the pancake mix/oatmeal, bypassed the summer sausage (note: sausage had not yet been massaged).

name: Bobby
description: Enchanted forest--great tent/tarp sites. Step crewling may or may not have tossed his cookies (or in this case, his pesto pasta) here in 2012...

name: Bobby
description: Enchanted Forest--good place for the mongols to stay.

name: Bobby
description: Sam Knob Parking lot/toilet. Favored location for crazy jesus man. Typically a fair amount of drunk rednecks in August.  Site of the conclusion of the epic showdown "Bay wrastles the honey pot," August 2011. Watch for spiders in the toilets.

name: Vern
description: Old butt knob and dog loser knob, as the name entails, are not fun to hike and have really no good views. Better to go on the 363.

name: Unknown
description: Across the road from the Looking Glass trailhead, there's a really good water hole with a rock to jump from!

name: Unknown
description: Lolz no campsites anywhere over here

name: Unknown
description: There is a high impact campsite somewhere in this region to the left of the trail, next to the river.  It can be a good place to camp, but it is BLACK ZONE if it is raining or if you think it might rain.

name: Unknown
description: Watch out in this area, the trail intersections are different on the USGS and the Nat Geo

name: Unknown
description: If crewlings only have the Nat Geo, they may struggle finding the trailhead when coming from the Devil's Courthouse drop off.  Consider giving them the USGS

name: Unknown
description: Bathrooms closed in March :(

name: Unknown
description: If you have crew members with bad joints or foot blisters, avoid going down this route because there is some aggressive downhill after old butt knob.  Take the 363 instead

name: Unknown
description: To find the VAM you have to keep an eye out and climb some rocks, you will not find it if you stay on the main trail.

name: Ari
description: Beware the USGS is horribly confusing/unclear in this area. On some PWILD USGS there are no trails marked, and on some there's a maze of trails marked.

name: Ari
description:
Sunny Point Cafe. So good.

Parking directions from their website: We have a small parking lot adjacent to the restaurant, including two reserved accessible spaces. There is also an overflow lot next to our garden.
Free street parking is available in marked places along Haywood Road in both directions and down Dorchester Street and State Street. Please take note of signed no parking zones, especially near intersections.

name: Unknown
description: Gear Locker

name: Unknown
description:
There is a great solo site behind a high impact site on the river near the waterfall. Be careful if you have solos during the weekend though, there might be randos. 
Also, if you give someone the cave as a solo site, watch out for strangers

name: Emily Stout
description: I always forget how steep this climb is until I'm on it and gasping for breath. Beware. Coming from Farlow Gap especially, getting over this mountain will take a while.

name: Emily Stout
description: AMAZING high impact campsite here. Flat, right next to a river, and lots of bearhang trees. Also a super cool suspension bridge.

name: Unknown
description: Bring two liters of water if you ever hike up Looking Glass...

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: Nothing to see here folks, just one of my favorite places to raise trout and christmas trees in the summer months.

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: You, my friend, are an adventurer. Keep being awesome and encourage others to similarly zoom out from a narrow perspective on life.

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: Some would say that Patagonia is the last wild setting on Earth. Obviously they never had you kids stay on their porch!

name: Sludwig
description:
Agreed with Krkr, great rock to jump off into a deep pool, although it is sometimes crowded on weekends. If you want to semi-nondirectively encourage nudity, use the alternate name of Skinny Dip Falls. 
Also, there are a couple decent camp sites if you scout near the banks downstream.

name: Sludwig
description: Nice tent campsite on a sandy beach between the river and the Art Loeb. Good spot for an early morning pick-up at Davidson if you don't want to pay to camp at Davidson River Campground. Downside: being able to see cars zoom by on 276.

name: Sludwig
description: In August 2013 we couldn't find the trailhead for 109 - the trail is there but I don't think it gets much use. Cross the river and bushwhack a bit up the (admittedly quite steep) bank, you'll find 109 running parallel to the river like the NatGeo shows. Enjoy the spider webs!

name: Sludwig
description: Not marked on NatGeo or USGS, but there is a connector trail to Devils Courthouse that takes you over the tunnel. Good signage and very obvious, only a 5-10 minute walk off the Mountains to Sea Trail to get to the top of Devil's Courthouse, instant VAM!

name: Sludwig
description: Eerily close to a pack of coyotes during the Wintry Mix of March 2014 - ate cold naan pizza because Pisgods did not answer pleas.

name: Ari
description: The trailhead here (for trail #113 Green Mountain) is extremely difficult to find. I think it's about 10 feet east of the bridge, but I'm not sure. Also, the trail is entirely on a ridge. And super steep for the first half mile.

name: Ari
description: The climb to the top of the rock formation just to the west of the path here is 30 seconds. It's a VAM that's mildly decent but also has that extra rewarding feeling of finding something off the path.

name: DChou
description: Yarr, here be water on the west side of the road coming out of a large pipe

name: DChou
description: The vote for 363 is seconded - plenty of stops to get water along the trail.

name: DChou
description: So uh, it doesn't necessarily look like it but 133 crosses the river literally (Not figuratively) 10 times without bridges so...if it's august do it during the day and it should be fine, but if it's march probably black zone. use bear hang cord to make a really long tarp line to give crewlings something to hold onto.

name: DChou
description: Your best bet for water near farlow

name: Rezree Niiro
description: High impact tarp site, a little slopey. Go down the trail for meh bear hangs. Try not to let your crewlings cook on the BRP.

name: Jaxxxon
description: They say that there's a rare flower that requires trace amounts of PWILD senior tears to grow. It's only been found here and in weird big circle patterns.

name: Jaxxxon
description: Weddings, old people, VAMs

name: Unknown
description: Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute. WHY HAVE WE NEVER GONE HERE?!

name: Temujin
description: The holy land of Mongolia

name: Ismaïl Omar Guelleh
description: Did you know the capital of Djibouti is Djibouti?!

name: Betty Bedouin
description: A Bedouin camp

name: Stout
description:
This road is entitled "Saddle Gap Road." On the USGS it is marked as leading to Saddle Gap. Alas, it is extremely overgrown, and leads nowhere. Don't lead hopeful crewlings up here in the middle of a night hike in the pouring rain.
xoxo Stout and Grant

name: Unknown
description: this climb is 10x steeper than it looks...lotsa fun with day 0 packs

name: bkim
description: THERE ARE NO SPOTS HERE FOR AUGUST.

name: bkim
description: aug 2014, 2 crewlings stung (i think by logs, but higher up from the area ari pointed out) be careful!

name: Jamie Bando
description: This would be a GREAT solo spot. This could be a pick up after solos to replace Mt. Pisgah and Pink Beds for solos. Go past the boggy area, past two small bridges, go up a hill and curve a bit before you get to the key spot. Explore and really go down some of the smaller little unofficial trails that come off the main one. There are great fire rings and large open areas that would work as a base camp and solo site. Not much foot traffic, came on a weekend.

name: Unknown
description: There is a path around here that will take you up to sunny slab. This is only relevant if you can't tell distances very well.

name: Mr. Ziegler
description: Hey Folks, there's a great little rock-slide waterfall that's fun for the whole family to slide down. Just keep heading towards the river through the campground that's just off the trail.

name: Iza
description: no camping here! have to go to bennett gap

name: Iza
description: there's cell service (for verizon)

name: Iza
description: not marked; you'll get to a sharp turn in the trail and be able to take a path down to the water. the water is kinda slimy

name: Iza
description: cell service definitely in the parking lot, suggested solo sites are on the loop coming out of the left of the parking lot and long the right trail (not through the meadow). suggest camping in the meadow; there's cell service and flat ground, but watch our for poison ivy there and at solo sites

name: Iza
description: campsites are on the trail up devils courthouse paved trail on the trail that stems out to the left going to the mountain to sea trail. there is also one on the side of the parking lot off the rock face. these are not the best, overgrown, and have thorns, but if you go to the right once up the rock face and keep walking down the trail for a few minutes, you can find some ok ones

name: Iza
description: bear hang trees extremely difficult to find

name: Addison Howenstine
description:
The trails here that we use for the fun run are poorly marked. Basically you just want to take the trail North as much as you can until you get to a road. You *will* get to a road (Road 225) if you never decide to take a trail South. When we did the route this year, the path we took looked nothing like the map and spat us out on the road in a v different location from where we wanted to be. Just take that road all the way East. NEVER. TURN. LEFT. 

Also, DO NOT EXPECT TO DRIVE DOWN 225! This is how runners got lost in 2014. You can drive up 475B, but 225 is CLOSED. You'll have to park at this intersection.

So basically for the fun run, take the Cove Creek Trail north to 225, turn Right, follow 225 (which won't be marked) to 475B, go down 475B, turn right on the paved road, *make sure that the babies run in the left lane against traffic because #safety, and then turn right up into Cove. This year (2015) the route was 9.5 miles because the route to get from Cove to 225 was pretty long.

Also watch out for misogynist bear killing hunters that may heckle girls.

name: George Bernard
description: The Bradley creek trail head is kinda hard to find. There's no sign or marker on it.  It's a moderately steep trail coming off the south side of the road. Obvi look at the map  when you're driving there. Its after the marked trail head on the north side of the road, and before the road blockage when you turn the corner. If you make it to some campsites called YG, that means yellow gap (too far). It is NOT through a campsite. Using parking lots to tell distance is ineffective (what even IS a parking lot in pisgah). Use the marked trail head to the north as a signal to slow down the convoy into search mode.

name: Michael Kim
description:
There are some really awesome cliff overhangs here right where the trail splits off. Almost directly south of the intersection is a sheer cliff with some areas to sit and they're surrounded by blueberry bushes. I definitely recommend spending at least a few moments there taking in the view and enjoying the bounty.

If southbound, a left will take you to Shitfuck Ridge and a right will take you towards Devil's Courthous.

name: Jared
description: You might think there would be camping at a place with a name like Saddle Gap. You would be wrong.

name: Ari Novick
description: This is a tunnel. I believe tunnels are PWILD black zone. But in the winter the BRP might be closed, so then...it's okay? I don't know. But I'm marking it so that you think to discuss it before you hit the trail.

name: Mike Kim
description: testy mctester

name: Dusty H
description: This mountain is EXHAUSTING. Make sure you know your crew before thinking about doing it the first day...

name: Dusty H
description: Some people may say that this is a route starting place. Do not trust them. This is false. The only way to get here is by ~hiking~

name: Dusty H
description: There's good camping down here by the river, but no good places for bear hangs and no good places to cook. Also, it's probably not ok to camp here ever again because of new Pisgah Bear rules, but just in case, keep this in mind.

name: Ari
description: Art Annex
